title: 108_hr482
content: The "Florida National Forest Land Management Act of 2003" defines terms like "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture and "State" as the State of Florida. It also addresses the sale or exchange of land. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land in Florida, specifically tract A-942a and A-942b in Santa Rosa County. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land in Florida, including tract A-942a and A-942b in Santa Rosa County, totaling approximately 101 acres, and tract A-942c in Okaloosa County, consisting of about 0.59 acres. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land in Florida, including tract A-942a and A-942b in Santa Rosa County, totaling approximately 101 acres, and tract A-942c in Okaloosa County, consisting of about 0.59 acres. Additionally, there are other tracts such as A-942d in Okaloosa County, covering around 79.90 acres, and A-943, the Okaloosa County Fairgrounds, with approximately 30.14 acres. Tract A-942d in Okaloosa County is approximately 79.90 acres, described as T. 2 N., R. 23 W., sec. 2, NW1/4 NE1/4 and NE1/4 NW1/4. Tract A-943 in Okaloosa County Fairgrounds is about 30.14 acres, described as T. 1 S., R. 24 W., sec. 26, S1/2. Tract A-944 in City Ball Park, Ft. Walton, Okaloosa County, is around 12.43 acres, described as T. 1 S., R. 24 W., sec. 26, S1/2. Tract A-945 is the Landfill-Golf Course Driving Range. Tract A-959 consists of 2 vacant lots on Micheaux Road in Bristol, Liberty County, totaling approximately 0.5 acres. Located southeast of Crestview, Okaloosa County, tract C-3m-d consists of approximately 40.85 acres. Tract A-959 includes 2 vacant lots on the north side of Micheaux Road in Bristol, Liberty County, totaling about 0.5 acres. Tract C-691 in Lake County consists of the subsurface and is located southwest of Astor, covering approximately 15.0 acres. Tract C-2208b in Lake County consists of approximately 39.99 acres, described as T. 17 S., R. 28 E., sec. 28, NW1/4 SE1/4. Tract C-691 in Lake County includes the subsurface rights to about 40.76 acres of land, described as T. 17 S., R. 29 E., sec. 25, SE1/4 NW1/4. Tract C-2209 in Lake County comprises approximately 127.2 acres, described as T. 17 S., R. 28 E., sec. 21, NE1/4 SW1/4, SE1/4 NW1/4, and SE1/4 NE1/4. Tract C-2209b in Lake County consists of about 39.41 acres. Tract C-2209 in Lake County is approximately 127.2 acres, described as T. 17 S., R. 28 E., sec. 21, NE1/4 SW1/4, SE1/4 NW1/4, and SE1/4 NE1/4. Tract C-2209b in Lake County is about 39.41 acres, described as T. 17 S., R. 29 E., sec. 32, NE1/4 SE1/4. Tract C-2209c in Lake County is around 40.09 acres, described as T. 18 S., R. 28 E., sec. 14, SE1/4 SW1/4. Tract C-2209d in Lake County is approximately 79.58 acres. Tract C-2210 in Marion County consists of approximately 30 acres, with 20 recreational residential lots on Lake Kerr, described as T. 13 S., R. 25 E., sec. 22. Approximately 79.58 acres of land in Marion County, including recreational residential lots on Lake Kerr and adjacent land, described in various sections and ranges. The curr_chunk describes tract C-2213 in the F.M. Arrendondo grant in Marion County, consisting of approximately 15.0 acres. The Secretary is allowed to modify land descriptions for sale or exchange purposes based on a survey. The Secretary is authorized to modify land descriptions for sale or exchange based on a survey or public interest. Offers may be solicited under specified terms and conditions. The Secretary may modify land descriptions for sale or exchange based on a survey or public interest. Offers may be solicited under specified terms and conditions, and rejected if deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. The Secretary has the authority to sell the land described. The Secretary has the authority to reject offers for land if they are deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. The land described in subsection (b) can be sold at public or private sale, with the option to use a real estate broker and pay them a commission. The Secretary can sell land described in subsection (b) at public or private sale, use a real estate broker, and pay them a comparable commission. The concurrence of the Secretary of the Air Force is required for the sale or exchange of certain parcels of land. The Secretary may sell land described in subsection (b) with the concurrence of the Secretary of the Air Force. Cash equalization may be accepted if the value of non-Federal land is less than the Federal land exchanged. The Secretary of the Air Force may accept a cash equalization payment exceeding 25% of the value of Federal land exchanged. Net proceeds from any sale or exchange under this Act will be deposited in the fund established by the Sisk Act. The Secretary may accept a cash equalization payment exceeding 25% of the Federal land value. Net proceeds from any sale or exchange will be deposited in the fund established by the Sisk Act for land acquisition in the National Forest System. The Secretary can use deposited funds for land acquisition and reimbursement of costs for land sales and exchanges under the Act. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION. Land acquired by the United States under this Act shall be subject to the Weeks Act and administered according to laws applicable to the National Forest System. The land described in section 3(b) is withdrawn from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws, except for valid existing rights. The land described in section 3(b) is withdrawn from the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 and from public land, mining, and mineral leasing laws, except for valid existing rights.
